questions.text: A young patient with hypoparathyroidism and tetany arrived with a missing thymus. In this situation, which of the following marked areas in the image is defective
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a defect in the third pharyngeal pouch, which has the thymus and the inferior parathyroid gland as its derivatives. The thymus and parathyroid glands in the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches fail to differentiate. caused by the loss of chromosome 22's long arm. questions.text: Which of the following is caused by RNAi in a gene?
questions.solution:
Gene knockdown- is an experimental method that lowers the expression of one or more genes in an organism. A short DNA or RNA oligonucleotide having a sequence corresponding to either a gene or an mRNA transcript can be used , or genetic modification can also result in the reduction.
Gene knockout, is a genetic technique that renders one of an organism's genes inoperative. ("knocked out" of the organism).

KO can also refer to the organism that possesses a gene knockout or the gene that has been deleted
Gene knockin- A genetic engineering technique known as a gene knock-in (abbreviation: KI) in molecular cloning and biology involves the one-for-one replacement of DNA sequence information in a genetic locus or the insertion of sequence information not present in the locus.

Gene knock up- upregulate the levels of a given protein while retaining its cell-type-specific regulation.

questions.text: In a fasting condition, which of the following is utilised by RBC?
questions.solution:
The brain and red blood cells require glucose during fasting and starvation; in the early stages of fasting, this is given by glycogen stores.
When insulin secretion is low, muscle and other tissues don't absorb glucose to conserve it; instead, they choose to use fatty acids (and eventually ketone bodies) as fuel.

ferroxidase, a.k.a. ceruloplasmin. It increases in all inflammatory conditions, collagen disorders, cancers, and pregnancy since it is an acute phase protein.

questions.text: The serum calcium level is regulated by which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
1. In addition to having significant impacts on bone formation and bone resorption, vitamin D has a strong influence on increasing calcium absorption from the intestinal tract.

The exchange between extracellular fluid and bone, intestinal reabsorption, and renal excretion are all regulated by parathyroid hormone.

deficiency of PTH leads to hypocalcemia, which frequently results in tetany. excess of PTH  results in the fast release of calcium salts from the bones and hypercalcemia in the extracellular fluid.

The thyroid gland's peptide hormone, calcitonin, tends to lower plasma levels of calcium. In general, it has the opposite effects of PTH.

To summarise remember the story of calcium metabolism as follows 

Whenever there is Calcium and Phosphate in blood, it will deposit in bone in form of Ca appatite. Vit D causes increased absorption of Ca and Phosphate from intestine and thereby deposits it in Bones. The prime role of Calcitonin is preventing the Ca from bone to reach the blood, or making it stay put in bones. 
Parathormone doesn’t care about anything else but Calcium, it increases Ca absorption via Vit D from GIT, but as vit D increases Phosphate absorption also, PTH causes excretion of Phosphate via urine to prevent the calcium from going into bone as Calcium appatite. 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 372,373,374,377

questions.text: A monkey has increased sexual activity, greater appetite, aggression, and no fear. This could be due to damage to which of the following structures
questions.solution:
Klüver-Bucy Syndrome, which is caused by bilateral amygdala ablation, is the most likely diagnosis. Amygdala is a group of several small nuclei that are situated close to the medial anterior pole of each temporal lobe. The monkey exhibits the following behavioural changes when the anterior portions of both temporal lobes are destroyed: is not afraid of anything, has extreme curiosity about everything, forgets things easily, has a propensity to put everything in its mouth and occasionally tries to eat solid objects frequently has a sex drive so strong that it tries to copulate with young animals, animals of the wrong sex, or even animals.

questions.text: Renal Autoregulation does not occur because of:
questions.solution:
THE MYOGENIC AUTOREGULATION OF GFR AND RENAL BLOOD FLOW The ability of individual blood vessels to resist stretching under elevated arterial pressure helps to maintain a reasonably steady renal blood flow and GFR. Stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction helps prevent excessive increases in renal blood flow and GFR by increasing vascular resistance when arterial pressure increases.

If there is decrease in GFR-> activation of RAAS pathway-> Angiotensin 2 helps in Na+ and water reabsorption increasing blood volume and mesangial cells contraction-> Increase in GFR 

Tubuloglomerular feedback also helps in maintaining auto-regulation of GFR

Therefore, option 2- Presympathetic nerves is the correct option.

questions.text:
A patient arrived with a history of renal failure, nodular lesions with cavitations in the lungs, ulcerative lesions in the
nasopharynx, and recurrent sinusitis.
Which of the following investigations is the most crucial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) ANCA for vasculitis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly known as Wegener’s Granulomatosis, is the most likely diagnosis based on the history provided in the question. 

GPA is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized by a triad of:
  • i. acute necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract (ear, nose, sinuses, throat) or the lower respiratory tract (lung) or both
  • ii. necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most prominent in the lungs and upper airways but also affecting other sites
  • iii. focal necrotizing, frequently crescentic glomerulonephritis.
The immunofluorescence patterns produced by ANCA antibodies are perinuclear and cytoplasmic, respectively
ANCA antibodies were previously grouped as c-ANCA (cytoplasmic) and p- ANCA (perinuclear). Now
1. Antilroteinase-3(PR3-ANCA, previously c-ANCA)
2. Anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO- ANCA, previously p-ANCA)

ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's

questions.text: Flow cytometry is represented by the following:
questions.solution:
Flow cytometry is typically represented by scatter plots and histograms generated from the data collected during the analysis. These plots visualize various parameters measured for individual cells or particles as they pass through the flow cytometer.Scatter plots: These plots typically display two parameters against each other, such as forward scatter (FSC) and side scatter (SSC). FSC measures the size of the cell or particle, while SSC provides information about its granularity or internal complexity. Scatter plots are useful for identifying different cell populations based on their size and internal characteristics.Histograms: Histograms represent the distribution of a single parameter measured by the flow cytometer, such as fluorescence intensity. Each bar in the histogram represents the number of cells or particles that fall within a specific range of values for that parameter. Histograms are commonly used to analyze the expression levels of specific proteins or markers within a cell population.These visual representations allow researchers to analyze the characteristics of individual cells or particles within a heterogeneous sample and identify different cell populations based on their properties.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 332.

Procedure:

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Endothelium
 
  • The endothelium of the alveoli is inflamed and swollen in COVID-19 ARDS.
  • Histopathological findings include diffuse alveolar damage, hyaline membrane formation, and inflammatory infiltrates.
  • The endothelial cells show signs of inflammation, such as cytoplasmic swelling and vacuolation.
  • The presence of viral particles within the endothelial cells and vascular endothelial damage contribute to vascular leakage and edema.
  • These histopathological changes lead to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure in severe cases of COVID-19 ARDS.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2270.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is admitted with intussusception and stomach pain. Intestinal polyps were discovered during the endoscopy. Below is a histopathological image from a biopsy that was collected. What kind of polyp is that
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Hamartomatous
 
  • The most common type of polyp in children is a hamartoma or juvenile polyp accounting for more than 95% of polyps found.
  • Juvenile polyps are typically found in 2 to 6 year old boys and girls but can be found in younger and older children up to about 10 years of age.
  • Hammartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract are rare compared to other types of GI polyps, yet they are the most common type of polyp in children.
  • The symptoms are usually rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, obstipation, anaemia, and/or small bowel obstruction.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1310.

questions.text: Which of the following is disrupted by cholera toxin (ZOT) in the intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Zonula occludens

Zonula occludens is disrupted by cholera toxin (ZOT) in the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Other than the well-known CT and TCP toxins, Vibrio has been extensively investigated with respect to Zot, RTX, and Ace among others. 
  • CT toxin- made up of A and B subunits. B binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors in intestinal mucosal cells. A causes production of Adenyl cyclase, this increases cAMP which activates CFTR causing increased secretion of chloride ions. 
  • Zot toxin- zona occludens toxin, alters the tight junctions. Induces a transitory reduction in transepithelial electrical resistance and an increase in transepithelial flux, increasing the permeability of TJs.
  • ACE toxin - integral membrane protein that affects ion transport, builds up in ligated rabbit ileal loops, and produces moderate diarrhea.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 12.

questions.text: After a dental procedure, a patient exhibits swelling and lump formation in the submandibular region. There are yellow particles in the discharge. Below is a picture of gram stain. What pathogen is to blame for this disease
questions.solution:
The condition is a chronic granulomatous infection that affects both humans and animals. The growth of indurated swellings, mostly in the connective tissue, suppuration, and the ejection of "sulphur granules" are its defining features. The granules are actually bacterial colonies, and they have the appearance of sun rays due to their thick network of thin, Gram-positive filaments and peripheral zone of inflated, radiating, club-shaped structures. It is thought that the "clubs" are antigen-antibody complexes. Characteristics of Actinomyces species identification: Bacilli that are gram-positive. Bacilli that are nonmotile, non sporing, and acid-fast. Create colonies with molar-tooth shapes. The direct fluorescent antibody test and the gel immunodiffusion test are used to identify species. Microaerophilic or anaerobic conditions are preferable for facultative anaerobe growth with the addition of 5-10% CO2.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 604.

questions.text: Topiramate is used to treat which of the following conditions:

  • MOA- It activates a hyperpolarizing K+ current, decreases voltage-gated Na+ currents in cerebellar granule cells, enhances postsynaptic GABA-A receptor currents, and restricts activation of the AMPA-kainate subtype(s) of glutamate receptors. Carbonic anhydrase's weak inhibitor.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is used to treat obesity over the long term?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Liraglutide
 
  • Because of growing evidence of cardiovascular and other hazards, sibutramine and rimonabant were no longer sold or used.   
  • Fenfluramine and Dexfenfluramine are non-selective 5-HT2 agonists. 
  • When combined with phentermine as Fen-Phen and Dex-Phen, they were somewhat effective. They were the most widely used and successful appetite suppressants. However, these were removed once it was shown that they contributed to heart valve abnormalities and pulmonary hypertension. 
  • Metformin, which is advised as the initial treatment for type 2 diabetes.
  • Liraglutide is a GLP1 agonist. It decreases appetite.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions calls for the use of inhaled nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pulmonary hypertension
 

  • Nitric Oxide inhalation dilates pulmonary vessels, resulting in decreased pulmonary vascular resistance and reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

  • Inhaled Nitric Oxide also improves oxygenation by reducing mismatch of ventilation and perfusion in the lung.

* Mechanism of Action:

Nitric oxide (NO) activates cytosolic soluble guanylyl cyclase → increased cGMP → causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) through a cGMP dependent protein kinase (PKG) → Reduced availability of phosphorylated (active) MLCK interferes with activation of myosin → it fails to interact with actin to cause contraction → Relaxation occurs.

* Indications: 

  • Therapeutic: The FDA has only approved chronic pulmonary neonatal hypertension as the use of inhaled NO. 

  • Diagnostic: During cardiac catheterization, inhaled NO can be utilized to assess the ability of patients with heart failure and newborns with congenital heart disease to dilate their blood vessels in the lungs to ascertain the alveolar-capillary unit's diffusion capacity (DL).

Option 1, 2 and 3 doesn't have an indication to use Inhaled nitric oxide.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: The CA Breast patient receiving paclitaxel experienced a fever and a decline in total count. Except for____, all of the subsequent antibiotics are usable.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Erythromycin
 
  • Paclitaxel can interact with several other medications.
  • The essential details on the drug-drug interactions associated with paclitaxel are mentioned below.
  • Cytochrome P450 enzymes: Paclitaxel undergoes primary metabolism through the cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzyme system, specifically CYP2C8 and CYP3A4.
  • Drugs that either inhibit or induce these enzymes can alter the metabolism and clearance of paclitaxel. Inhibitors of CYP2C8 and CYP3A4: Drugs such as ketoconazole, erythromycin, clarithromycin, fluoxetine, and grapefruit juice can inhibit CYP2C8 and CYP3A4.
  • This inhibition can result in elevated plasma concentrations, potentially increasing the risk of paclitaxel-related toxicities. Inducers of CYP2C8 and CYP3A4: Drugs such as rifampin, phenytoin, carbamazepine, and St John's wort can induce CYP2C8 and CYP3A4. This induction can lead to diminished paclitaxel plasma concentrations, potentially compromising its efficacy.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 160.

questions.text: What medication, as depicted, works via the following mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vancomycin

* Mechanisms of action and Resistance Factors:
  • By tightly adhering to the d-Ala-d-Ala terminus of developing peptidoglycan pentapeptide, vancomycin prevents the formation of cell walls. 
  • The peptidoglycan is weakened as a result of this inhibition of transglycosylase, which prevents further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan and makes the cell more vulnerable to lysis. 
  • Resistance to vancomycin in enterococci is caused by change of the d-Ala-d-Ala binding site of the peptidoglycan building block in which the terminal d-Ala is replaced by d-lactate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

choices.text: Half-life remains same and plasma concentration doubles.

questions.text: When a drug's dose is doubled while adhering to first order kinetics, what happens to the drug's half life and plasma concentration
questions.solution:
The correct option is (1) Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles.

  • In first-order kinetics, the rate of drug elimination is proportional to its plasma concentration.
  • The half-life (t½) remains constant because it depends on the drug's clearance and volume of distribution, which do not change with dose.
  • Plasma concentration doubles because the drug is eliminated at a proportional rate, maintaining first-order kinetics.



 Fig: Plasma concentration-time plot of a drug eliminated by first order kinetics after intravenous injection

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 38.

choices.text: Fixed dose combination over single dose drugs

questions.text: Except for the following, all are criteria for essential drugs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Fixed dose combination over single dose drugs

The WHO has defined Essential Medicines (drugs) as “those that satisfy the priority healthcare needs of the population.”
They are selected with due regard to public health relevance, evidence on efficacy and safety, and comparative cost effectiveness.


 *The WHO's criteria for an Essential drug- 
  • Adequate information on its adequacy and safety should be available from clinical research. 
  • available in a form whose quality, including bioavailability, and storage stability can be guaranteed. 
  • The pattern of prevalent diseases, the availability of facilities and qualified staff, financial resources, as well as genetic, demographic, and environmental factors should all be taken into consideration while choosing drug. 
  • When two or more drugs are similar, a decision should be made based on the relative efficacy, safety, quality, price, and availability of each. A key factor to take into account is the cost-benefit ratio.
  • Comparative pharmacokinetic characteristics and available manufacturing and storage options in the area.
  • The majority of basic medications ought to be single compounds. Only when the dosage of each ingredient satisfies the needs of a specific population group and when the combination has a demonstrated benefit in therapeutic impact, safety, adherence, or reducing the establishment of drug resistance, could products with fixed ratio combinations be included. 
  • Choosing essential drugs should be an ongoing process that takes into consideration the shifting priorities for public health action, epidemiological conditions, the availability of better medications/formulations, and advancements in pharmacological knowledge. 
  • Recently, the importance of choosing important medications based on clinically sound treatment recommendations has been stressed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 6.

questions.text: Clopidogrel was given to a patient who had suffered an ischemic stroke. He experienced another stroke episode even after six months of therapy. Which of the following describes clopidogrel's failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CYP2C19 inhibition
 
  • Clopidogrel is a prodrug only 50% of the ingested drug is absorbed, out of this only a fraction is activated in the liver by two step metabolism into an active thiol metabolite via CYP2CI9.
  • CYP2C19 inhibition by proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole, lansoprazole, dexlansoprazole, and pantoprazole) may reduce conversion to the active metabolite of clopidogrel, which may contribute to the lower efficacy of clopidogrel when coadministered with proton pump inhibitors.
  • Since CYP2C19, exhibits genetic polymorphism, the activation of clopidogrel and consequently its antiplatelet action shows high interindividual variability. Some patients are nonresponsive.
* Mechanism of action
Clopidogrel reduces ADP-induced aggregation by inhibiting the P2Y12 receptors on the surface of platelets. This Gi-coupled GPCR inhibits adenylyl cyclase and lowers cAMP. It permanently reduces platelet function.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 678.

questions.text:
Which of the following anomalies is observed in a case of drowning in sea water?
i. Hypernatremia
ii. Hypercalcemia
iii. Hypermagnesemia
iv. Hyponatremia
v. Myocardial anoxia
questions.solution:
Due to the osmotic pressure effect, the salt water that has entered the lungs and is hypertonic takes water from the blood in pulmonary circulation.
This causes fulminating pulmonary edema, hemoconcentration, hypovolemia of the blood, hypoxia, and circulatory shock, which are all followed by cardiac standstill or systole and death. Hemoconcentration leads to Myocardial anoxia. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: What is the most common way for retinoblastoma to spread?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Direct spread via Optic nerve (Answer has been confirmed by Pediatric Oncology Faculty at AIIMS, Delhi - Kindly see the reference article by them)
 
  • Retinoblastoma is a common cancerous tumour that develops in one or both eyes from the neurosensory retina.
  • Retinoblastoma (RB) gene has been discovered as 14 band on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q 14) and is a 'cancer suppressor' or 'antioncogenic' gene. Retinoblastoma is caused by the deletion or inactivation of the RB gene by two mutations (Knudson's two-hit hypothesis).
  • The most frequent presenting symptom is leukocoria, or a yellowish-white pupillary reflex (cat's eye appearance in amaurosis).
  • Common spread involves direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.
Reference: Aditya K Gupta et al https://pm.amegroups.org/article/view/5703/html

questions.text: A child with proptosis. On histopathology shows small cells and are desmin positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rhabdomyosarcoma
 
The majority of cases (90%) of this primary orbital tumor in children occur before the age of 15, males are more likely to develop it than females. 
Three different histopathological subtypes: 
1. Embryonal sarcoma, which is the most prevalent.
2. Alveolar sarcoma
3. Pleomorphic Sarcoma (least common)
 
  • It typically shows up in a child between the ages of 7-8 as a sudden, fast progressing proptosis, mimicking an acute inflammatory process.
  • Superonasal quadrant involvement by the tumour is common. 
  • Desmin is an intermediate filament protein linked to skeletal and smooth muscles. 
  • One of the most sensitive rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) indicators, including the majority of the poorly-differentiated cases, is desmin. 
  • It is not totally specific though. It is unable to discriminate between leiomyosarcoma and RMS.

choices.text: Triad of SNHL, enamel hypoplasia and calcification in 20-30%
Mothers with IgG-CMV have low risk of transmitting disease
asymptomatic CMV have high risk of SNHL later

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about CMV infection?
questions.solution:
Correct option is (2).
Lets rule out the options.

  1. Triad of SNHL, enamel hypoplasia and calcification in 20-30%: . The classic triad associated with congenital CMV infection includes sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), microcephaly, and chorioretinitis, but not typically enamel hypoplasia. Enamel hypoplasia can occur, but it's not part of the classic triad.

  2. Mothers with IgG-CMV have low risk of transmitting disease: This is true. Mothers who have IgG antibodies (indicative of past infection) typically have a lower risk of transmitting CMV to their infants compared to those with a primary infection.

  3. Asymptomatic CMV have high risk of SNHL later: Asymptomatic congenital CMV infection can still be associated with a risk of developing SNHL later in life but not higher risk than symptomatic patients 

  4. Only 20-30% CMV infection is symptomatic:Most congenital CMV infections are asymptomatic, with symptomatic cases representing a smaller percentage (about 10-20%)

Hence, statement regarding CMV infection is (2) Mothers with IgG-CMV have low risk of transmitting disease is true.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the relationship between prevalence and sensitivity, specificity, and PPV?
questions.solution:
1. A screening test's positive predictive value (PPV) is dependent on its sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence of disease in a population.

Sensitivity- the ability of a test to correctly identify true positives.

Specificity- the ability of a test to correctly identify true negatives.
 

 

The “predictive value of a positive test” indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has, in fact, the disease in question. The more prevalent a disease is in a given population, the more accurate will be the predictive value of a positive screening test.
The predictive value of a positive result falls as disease prevalence declines.

choices.text: 6 correlation coefficient between each group's weight and height.

questions.text:
Referring to the illustration, a homogenous sample was divided into 4 groups, with a 0.6 correlation coefficient between each group's weight and height.
What will be the combined overall correlation of the full group?
questions.solution:
The total will be equal to 0.6 because it comes from homogeneous samples.
 

Correlation coefficient is used to gauge how closely two variables relate to one another. 

The most common correlation coefficient is Pearson's correlation, aka Pearson's R, is frequently employed in linear regression.

  • If the correlation coefficient is 1, it means that there is a fixed proportional increase in the other variable for every increase in the positive variable. 
  • If the correlation coefficient is -1, it means that for every positive increase in one variable there is a negative decrease of fixed proportion in the other.
  • Zero indicates that there is neither a positive nor a negative rise for every increment. These two are not related.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the equivalence margin graph is/are correct?

(i) A represents Superiority of new treatment
(ii) I represents Inferiority of new treatment
(iii) E represents Non inferior treatment
(iv) C is inconclusive
questions.solution:
1. EQUIVALENCE MARGIN GRAPH



A represents Superiority of new treatment
I represents Inferiority of new treatment
E represents Non inferior treatment
C represents equivalence
 

 Equivalence Margin Graph

 

  1. Comparator Line (or Reference Line):

    • This is a central line representing the efficacy of the standard or comparator treatment.
    • It’s usually positioned at zero or at a fixed point, indicating the established baseline for comparison.

  2. Equivalence Zone (or Equivalence Margin):

    This is a range around the comparator line, bounded by upper and lower margins. It defines the range within which a new treatment is considered to have "equivalent" efficacy to the standard treatment. For example, an equivalence margin might be set as ±5 units around the comparator. If the efficacy of a new treatment falls within this range, it’s considered to be equivalently effective.
  3. Superiority and Inferiority Regions:
    • To the right of the equivalence zone is the superiority region, where treatments exceeding the comparator's efficacy are plotted.
    • To the left of the equivalence zone is the inferiority region, where treatments that are less effective than the comparator are plotted.
    • These regions help researchers see if a treatment is significantly better or worse than the comparator.
 



A superiority trial is done to show that the new drug is superior to the standard drug.
A non inferiority trial is done to show that the new drug is not worse than the standard drug.
This is done for newer interventions or drugs that may be less costly, less invasive and have fewer side effects.



Online reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24228861/

questions.text: You work at PHC as a medical officer. Transferring 50 patients with anti-hypertensive needs from the periphery to your PHC. 40 persons must take amlodipine (5mg PO). Amlodipine should not be used by 10 persons, thus they must begin using Lisinopril instead (10mg PO).PHC will receive drugs once each month. In total, how many medications will you order, and what will the reorder factor be?
questions.solution:
You may determine how many of each item you need to order by using the reorder factor, which is a numerical value. 

It calls for keeping enough product on hand to meet demand until your next reorder, as well as an extra buffer to guard against unforeseen increases in demand or delays in delivery or pickup. 

If supplies are supplied once a month, the reorder factor is 2 (1 x 2 = 2).
If supplies are delivered every three months (3 x 2 = 6), the reorder factor is 6.
If supplies are delivered every six months (6 x 2 = 12), the reorder factor is 12.

Tablet Amlodipine:40 x 1 x 30= 1200 tablets are required in a month

Tablet Lisinopril: 10 x 1 x 30 = 500 tablets are required in a month.

Total number of drugs required combined: 1500 tablets

Reorder factor for supplies delivered once a month is 2.

1500 x 2 = 3000 tablets has to be ordered in a month.


Online reference: 9. Rettig RA, Earley LE, and Merrill RA Editors. Food and Drug Administration Advisory Committees in Committee to Study the Use of Advisory Committees, Institute of Medicine;1992.

questions.text: Three days after having a cholecystectomy, the patient came with tachycardia and stomach pain. He has an 11,000/mm3 WBC count. A 5 x 5 cm collection in the right hypochondrium was observed on USG. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. USG guided pig tail drainage

The given scenario is of Bile leak followed by development of abscess. 
 
* Pigtail drainage:
 
  • In image-guided percutaneous drainage, an abscess or other collection of fluid or air is drained using a catheter (a small tube). 
  • Abscess development is the most frequent complication of leftover gallstones following cholecystectomy. 
  • The intraperitoneal and extraperitoneal spaces are where the abscess is located. 
  • Pigtail catheters are a safe and non-invasive alternative to tube thoracostomy that provide effective treatment for minor effusions and pneumothorax.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 68.

questions.text: A patient has several gallstones, each measuring 12 mm in diameter, and their S. Bilirubin, ALP, and GGT levels are all increased five times above the recommended level. What is the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. ERCP
 
  • Magnetic repulsion Cholangiopancreatography is used to determine the obstruction's source. 
  • ERCP is the best choice if the patient had jaundice. MRCP is performed because the serum bilirubin level is within normal limits. 
  • MRCP is an excellent imaging of the gallbladder and biliary system using a non-invasive method. 
  • The accuracy of MRCP's non-invasive biliary tract imaging is comparable to that of direct cholangiography performed using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC). 
  • The biliary tree can be photographed to show ductal obstruction, strictures, or other intraductal abnormalities.
MRCP- 
A rapid, noninvasive modality that provides detailed bile duct and pancreatic duct images equal to those of ERCP Sensitivity ≈93% and specificity ≈94%, comparable with those for ERCP Useful for examining nondilated ducts, particularly at the distal portion, which often is not well visualized by US Adjacent structures such as the liver and pancreas can be examined at the same time
Recommended for patients with low to moderate clinical probability of choledocholithiasis.

ERCP- 
ERCP is the standard diagnostic test for stones in the BD, with sensitivity and specificity of ≈95%Use of ERCP to extract stones (or at least drain infected bile) is life-saving in severe cholangitis and reduces the need for BD exploration at the time of cholecystectomy Recommended for patients with a high clinical probability of choledocholithiasis
When contrast agent flows retrograde into the gallbladder, stones appear as filling defects and can be detected with a sensitivity rate of ≈80%, but US remains the mainstay for confirming cholelithiasis



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1236.

* Radiotherapy :
  • In some patients with significant local recurrence risks (I.e Younger women, those with high-grade tumours, and those with involved resection margins are more likely to experience local recurrence) following mastectomy, radiotherapy to the chest wall is recommended. 
  • This includes patients with large tumours, numerous nodes that are positive, or significant lymphovascular invasion. 
  • In women with node-positive breast cancer, there is some evidence that postoperative chest wall radiation increases survival. 
  • Combining conservative surgery with radiation to the residual breast tissue is common.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 845.

questions.text: When suturing, what is the angle between the skin and the needle?
questions.solution:

choices.text: Wait for bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.text:
A little child with a perineal injury visited the emergency room. Examination reveals blood at the meatus and no recent urination; the bladder is not palpable.
What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
The bulbar urethra has ruptured, which is the most likely diagnosis.
  • The next course of action in management is to wait and observe as the bladder is not full.
  • Doing suprapubic aspiration after the bladder is full is advised.
  • This lessens urine extravasation and makes it possible to determine the severity of the urethral damage by investigations.
  • Using water-soluble contrast, urethrography is used to make the diagnosis.
  • A catheter should be inserted using a Seldinger technique through a percutaneous suprapubic puncture to empty a full bladder. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1766.

questions.text: A patient came in with a firm, painless testicular tumor and high LDH. What is the ideal course of action moving forward?
questions.solution:
• A testicular tumor case is suspected based on the provided clinical situation. The patient typically arrives with a lump in the testes that doesn't hurt. 
  • The testis may feel heavy if it is two or three times its normal size, but only a small percentage of people report pain. An ultrasound scan of the testis is used to confirm the diagnosis. Staging is a crucial step in treatment planning for confirmed patients. 
  • Before an orchidectomy, blood is drawn to check the levels of tumour markers, which are elevated in about 50% of cases. 
  • An inguinal incision is used to perform the orchidectomy. The external oblique aponeurosis is divided to reveal the spermatic cord, and a soft clamp is placed across the cord to prevent the spread of cancerous cells as the testis is removed.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1571.

Since pain is not given in the options - Nausea and Vomiting (PONV) is the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: How soon may an elective surgery be performed on a symptomatic COVID patient who doesn't need to be admitted to the hospital?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 6week
 
  1. After recovery following COVID-19, the scheduling of elective surgery is determined using both severity- and symptom-based categories. 
  2. 4 weeks for a patient who is asymptomatic or who only has minor, non-respiratory symptoms. 
  3. 6 weeks for a symptomatic patient (e.g., cough, dyspnea) who did not need hospitalization. 
  4. 8 to 10 weeks for a symptomatic diabetic, immunocompromised, or hospitalized patient.
  5. 12 weeks for a patient who was admitted to an intensive care unit as a result of contracting COVID-19.
Reference: Glasbey JC, Dobbs TD, Abbott TEF. Can patients with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection safely undergo elective surgery? Br J Anaesth. 2022 Jun;128(6):909-911. doi: 10.1016/j.bja.2022.03.003. Epub 2022 Mar 10. PMID: 35369990; PMCID: PMC8907026.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the way a local anesthetic works?
questions.solution:

* Mechanism of Action:
  • The LAs prevent nerve conduction by reducing the entry of Na+ ions during the action potential's upstroke (AP). 
  • The Na permeability does not rise in response to an impulse or stimulus because the LAs interact with a receptor inside a voltage-sensitive channel and raise the threshold of channel opening.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is inhaled nitric oxide used?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Pulmonary hypertension

NO increases cGMP levels in vascular smooth muscle, which acts as a vasodilator and relaxes other smooth muscle. Inhaling NO increases blood flow to the areas of the lung exposed to it and lowers pulmonary vascular resistance.
Uses: 
  • Therapeutic: The FDA has only approved chronic pulmonary neonatal hypertension as the use of inhaled NO. 
  • Diagnostic: Inhaled NO can be utilized during cardiac catheterization to assess the ability of patients with heart failure and newborns with congenital heart disease to dilate their blood vessels in the lungs. It can also be used to calculate the diffusion capacity (DL) across the alveolar-capillary unit.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2124-2128.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Nasociliary nerve
 
  1. Nasociliary nerve block- Close to the ethmoidal foramen, the nasociliary nerve is blocked before it splits into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the infratrochlear nerve. 
  2. The nasociliary nerve is blocked before its division into nasal branches of the anterior ethmoidal nerve and the infratrochlear nerve, and near the ethmoidal foramen. A 25- or 27-gauge needle is inserted 1 cm above the medial canthus, halfway between the posterior palpebral fold and the eyebrow. It is then directed medially and backward in contact with the bony roof of the orbit. At a depth of 1.5 cm the needle should be at the anterior ethmoidal foramen, and a maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected after a negative aspiration test.
  3. The external nasal branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve can be blocked by infiltration at the junction of nasal bone with cartilage.
  4. Blocking this nerve can be useful in treating conditions such as cluster headaches, migraines, and trigeminal neuralgia

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2412-2414.

questions.text: What are the best investigations for determining the cause of primary hyperparathyroid adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Sestamibi scan.
 
  • The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma. 
  • The investigation of choice for localization of parathyroid adenoma is Tc-99m Sestamibi scan. 
  • Tc-99m Sestamibi scan- Nuclear medicine scan based on the principle of presence of high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content in parathyroid adenoma and 
  • Sestamibi is a lipophilic cation and has a tendency to passively diffuse across cell membrane and thereby accumulate in mitochondria. 
Other imaging modalities: 
USG- Cannot penetrate sternum/clavicle making visualization of mediastinal parathyroid tissue difficult. 
Four dimension CT- It is considered as gold standard in imaging for parathyroid adenoma. 


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 877.

questions.text: Which investigation is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CT.

The given investigation modality is non-contrast CT scan of abdomen. It is identified by hyperdense (white) appearance of bones. 

The appearance of important structures on CT scan are as follows:
a.    Hypodense- black/dark. 
•    Air- Lungs, paranasal sinuses, middle ear cavity
•    Water- CSF in ventricles, bile in gallbladder and biliary tree, urine in urinary bladder
•    Fat- Subcutaneous tissue, mesentery and omentum. 

b.    Isodense-Gray. 
•    Soft tissues in the body such as brain, liver, spleen, kidneys appear isodense. 

c.    Hyperdense-White/bright. 
•    Bones- Skull, ribs, middle ear ossicles
•    Calcification- Basal ganglia, calcified fibroid, calculus 
•    Acute hemorrhage and foreign body such as glass, bullet, shrapnel. 

Option B-MRI 
•    MRI detects signal intensity arising from nuclei/protons 
•    Appearance is described as hypointense- dark, isointense- intermediate and hyperintense- white.
•     Simple trick to identify MRI is to look for bones which appear black/hypointense as compared to CT scan where they appear white/hyperdense. 

Option C- Contrast Study
•    Involves injection of contrast material to evaluate structures not identified by conventional imaging. 
•    Examples of contrast study include:
  • Digital subtraction angiography
  • Barium studies
  • Intravenous pyelogram 
  • Micturating cystourethrogram
  • Retrograde urethrogram 
  • Hysterosalpingography
Option D- Angiography
•    In angiography, contrast material is injected in the blood vessels and images are acquired using X-Rays, CT or MRI. 

The image seen is from a CT scan. A series of x-rays, a type of radiation on the electromagnetic spectrum, are used to make CT scans. The detectors in the scanner measure the difference between the x-rays that are absorbed by the body and the x-rays that are transmitted through the body. The scanner emits x-rays at the patient from a range of angles. Attenuation is the term used for this.

 
Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 469, 472.

questions.text: The antenatal USG of a female who is 20 weeks pregnant is provided below. Which congenital anomaly is most likely to exist?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Anencephaly.
 
Anencephaly:
  • Most severe form of cranial neural tube defect (NTD)
  • Occurs due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore leading to failed crania vault development and unprotected exposed brain tissue (exencephaly).
  • Subsequent destruction/autolysis leaves a flattened, amorphous vascular-neural mass characteristic of anencephaly. 
Antenatal ultrasound:
 
  • Sonographically detectable as early as 11 weeks. 
  • Sonographic features of anencephaly include:
  • Absence of parenchymal tissue above the orbits along with calvarium 
  • Small amount of neural tissue may be present which is termed as exencephaly
  • Less than expected value for crown-rump length (CRL)
  • "Frog eye" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance- Seen in coronal plane due to absent cranial bone along with brain and bulging orbits
  • Polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 231, 1805, 1986.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 202, 471, 472, 736.

questions.text: What is the current IOC for myocarditis?
questions.solution:
The current investigation of choice (IOC) for diagnosing myocarditis is:

Option 1. MRI (specifically, Cardiac MRI)

Cardiac MRI is the most useful and preferred imaging modality because it can non-invasively assess myocardial inflammation, edema, and fibrosis, and it offers tissue characterization that is helpful in diagnosing myocarditis.

Other options:

  • Option 2: BNP: B-type natriuretic peptide levels can be elevated in myocarditis, but they are non-specific and more commonly used to assess heart failure.
  • Option 3: Endomyocardial biopsy: While this is considered the gold standard for a definitive diagnosis, it is invasive and generally reserved for cases where MRI and clinical findings are inconclusive or when there is severe disease with rapid deterioration.
  • Option 4: D-dimer: D-dimer is primarily used to assess clotting abnormalities, such as in cases of suspected pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis or DIC, and is not specific to myocarditis.

Therefore, Cardiac MRI is the current non-invasive imaging of choice for diagnosing myocarditis.


.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 315, 332-334.

questions.text: An HIV-positive 45-year-old woman who was administered ergotamine for migraines experienced searing and non-palpable dorsalis pedalis discomfort in the middle of her leg. What's the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Correct option is 1: Ergotism.
  • The given imaging modality is CT angiography of lower limb vessels which is showing non-opacification of lower limb vessels distal to bilateral superficial femoral artery. 
  • The given radiographic findings along with history of consumption of ergotamine for migraine points towards diagnosis of ergotism which is characterized by dry gangrene due to vasoconstriction  
  • Ergotism affects the more poorly vascularized distal structures, such as the fingers and toes. 
  • Clinical features include:
    • Desquamation or peeling
    • Weak peripheral pulses
    • Loss of peripheral sensation 
    • Edema
    • Gangrene
  • Ergotism is the result of chronic ergot poisoning, which is traditionally brought on by consuming the alkaloids made by the fungus Claviceps purpurea. The fungus's ergotamine-ergocristine alkaloids cause vasoconstriction, which leads to dry gangrene.
  • It affects the distal structures that have less blood flow, like the fingers and toes. Desquamation or peeling, weak peripheral pulses, loss of peripheral feeling, edema, and eventually the death and loss of affected tissues are some of the symptoms. Vasodilators are used to treat vasoconstriction.

In atherosclerosis there would be focal luminal narrowing of the artery.


Reference: KD Tripathi Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page no 191.
Jeong, Seok-Young et al. “Ergotism with ischemia in all four extremities: a case report.” Journal of clinical neurology (Seoul, Korea) vol. 2,4 (2006): 279-82. doi:10.3988/jcn.2006.2.4.279

questions.text: Recognize the MRI sequence.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SWI.
 
The image shown is susceptibility weighted image (SWI) and it shows microhemorrhages as hypointense foci. 

Susceptibility weighted imaging (SWI) 
  • MRI sequence sensitive to compounds which distort the local magnetic field.
  • Useful in detecting blood products, calcium, etc.
  • The most common use of SWI is for identification of small amounts of hemorrhage/blood products or calcium, both of which are difficult to appreciate on other MRI sequences. 





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1406, 1407.
Gaillard F, Foster T, Alhusseiny K, et al. Susceptibility weighted imaging. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-13858

questions.text: The following CXR is performed on a patient  who presented with sporadic abdomen pain and minor upper abdominal discomfort. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1- 

The given chest X-Ray shows a raised Hemi-diaphragm on one side , which is consistent with Eventration of the diaphragm. Eventration is charecterized by an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm due to a congenital or acquired weakness of the diaphragmatic muscle, resulting in an abnormally high but intact diaphragm. 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernias: If the elevation was due to CDH there would be evidence of abdominal organs such as bowel loops or abdominal organs within the thoracic cavity


Option D- Gastric volvulus is a relatively uncommon condition presenting with Borchardt’s triad which includes:
  • Sudden onset severe abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with production of little vomitus 
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube. 
  • Gastric volvulus is broadly divided into 2 types- organoaxial and mesentroaxial. 
  • Chest X-Ray shows upside down stomach which is intra-thoracic in location along with retrosternal or mediastinal air-fluid level. 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 377.

Radswiki T, Campos A, Silverstone L, et al. Diaphragmatic eventration. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 14 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-13370

questions.text: The results of a CECT performed for examination on a 35-year-old female with a Bosnian Type 3 Cyst are displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Angiomyolipoma.
 
  • Renal angiomyolipomas- Benign renal neoplasms composed of vascular, smooth muscle and fat elements. 
  • Considered a type of PEComas due to presence of perivascular epithelioid differentiation. 
  • They can be encountered sporadically as well as a part of tuberous sclerosis. 
  • Clinically, they can either be asymptomatic or can present with retroperitoneal hemorrhage (Wunderlich syndrome). 
  • The risk of bleeding is proportional to the size of lesion. 

Radiographic features-
  • USG- Hyperechoic lesion in the cortex due to the presence of macroscopic fat. ( Remember, fat appears hyperechoic- bright on USG )
  • CT scan, cornerstone feature is to demonstrate the presence of macroscopic fat seen as hypoattenuating lesion which is black in color. 
  • MRI- Used to differentiate fat containing AMLs from an entity known as fat poor AML.

Treatment- 

Indication for intervention with either embolization or resection with partial nephrectomy are-
  • Asymptomatic lesions > 4 cm in dimension. 
  • Symptomatic AML
Lesions presenting with retroperitoneal hemorrhage as in the given clinical scenario require emergency embolization as a life saving measure. 

Option B- Oncocytoma. Predominantly benign lesion characterized by presence of a sharp central stellate scar easily seen on CT scan. 



Option C- RCC. 
CT is the investigation of choice for both diagnosis as well as staging where it appears as a heterogeneously enhancing mass lesion.
 


Option D- Renal cyst. It is a broader term which includes cystic lesions of kidney. They can either be simple or complicated. Bosniak system of classification is used for characterization of renal cysts. It is based on their appearance on contrast-enhanced CT scan. 
 




Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 796-799.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who has right hemiparesis and aphasia for the past two hours arrives at the casualty. Random blood sugar reading is 106 and BP is 160/110. NCCT is normal. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: CT Angiography.
 
  • The given clinical scenario of hemiparesis with aphasia along with a clear NCCT points towards diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke with possibility of left MCA occlusion. 
  • Therefore, the patient should be taken for CT angiography as it can accurately detect large vessel occlusion. 
  • CT angiography determines if there is an emergent large vessel occlusion ( EVLO )
  • If EVLO is present, an additional CT perfusion image is acquired to look for mismatch ratio of penumbra to ischemic core in order to triage patients for management by intra-arterial mechanical thrombectomy using a retriever device. 
  • Mechanical thrombectomy should be done ideally within 6 hours and not beyond 24 hours of symptom onset. 
  • MRI with diffusion weight imaging (DWI) is superior to NCCT for detecting an acute infarct. 
  • However, it is not preferred because of longer scan completion time, limited availability and higher cost. 

Note- First line treatment for acute stroke is intravenous thrombolysis using alteplase and should be administered within a window period of 4.5 hours. However, mechanical thrombectomy is indicated as well for acute ischemic stroke if there is a large vessel occlusion in anterior circulation within 6 hours. Therefore, CT angiography would be the next best step in management to look for large vessel occlusion. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3334-3336.

Match the following with the correct option.

Name of fracture Fracture site

questions.solution:
• Boxers fracture- 5th metacarpal
  • Bennets fracture- 1st metacarpal
  • March fracture- 2 nd metatarsal
  • Jones fracture- 5th metatarsal

Boxer's fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone.
Bennett's fracture is a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal bone, which is seen in individuals who fall on an outstretched hand with the thumb in abduction.
March fracture is a stress fracture of the metatarsal bones most commonly the 2nd metatarsal.
Jones fracture is a fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal bone of the foot, which is commonly seen in individuals who participate in sports that involve running and jumping


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 367 Annexure 2

questions.text: What is the most delayed indication of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
1.  An externally applied compressive force or an expanding internal force are the two most frequent causes (such as an arterial bleed, overexertion, or a fracture) for compartment syndrome.  
    Features: 
  • Severe pain (a "bursting" sensation) is the earliest of the "classic" symptoms followed by Pallor and paraesthesia. 
  • Pulselessness 
  • Paralysis is last to appear.

choices.text: Open reduction and repair of posterior wall acetabulum
Immediate closed reduction and check for hip stability.

questions.text: Following an RTA, a 14-year-old boy suffered severe hip discomfort due to a posterior hip dislocation. What is the ideal next step in management?
questions.solution:
1. Reduction of a dislocated hip is urgent because the longer the head is out, the greater the likelihood that it may become avascular. (Manipulate the hip when under a general anaesthetic.) 

If the acetabulum has a chip fracture, it typically heals when the head is reduced. In the following situations, open reduction may be necessary: 

  • when closed reduction is unsuccessful, typically in patients who present late; 
  • when an intra-articular loose fragment prevents accurate reduction;
  • when the acetabular fragment is large and originates from the weight-bearing portion of the acetabulum. The hip becomes unstable with such a fracture.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 130

choices.text: Compartment syndrome can be seen in open fractures

questions.text: Which of the following statements about open fracture is false?
questions.solution:
• Tibia bone is commonly involved in open fractures due to its location and vulnerability to injury.
  • Immediate debridement, which involves the removal of any foreign material or contaminated tissue from the wound, is crucial in reducing the risk of infection in open fractures.
  • Compartment syndrome is a potential complication of open fractures where pressure builds up within the muscles and tissues surrounding the fracture, leading to decreased blood flow and potential nerve damage.It could be related to the injury or related with the treatment ie Cast Application
  • Open fractures are often associated with additional injuries- Most serious ones are Neurovascular injuries, hence it is the wrong statement.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 7,21,22,155

choices.text: Calcium is decreased and ALP is increased

questions.text: What are the levels of ALP and calcium in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
1. Osteoporosis is defined by abnormally low bone mass and structural defects in the bone. As a result, the bone becomes unusually brittle and more prone to fracture in a person of that age, sex, and race. 

Alkaline phosphatase, phosphates, and serum calcium are all within normal ranges. Plasma albumin and total plasma proteins may be low. 

The gold standard for determining bone mass is the DEXA scan, an X-ray-based bone densitometry. 

- Normal bone density is defined as a T-score of -1.0 or higher. 

- T-score between -1.0 and -2.5 Denotes osteopenia or low bone density.

- A T-score of 2.5 or less denotes osteoporosis.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 309

questions.text: Which of the following is not a possible cause of secondary amenorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Kalman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea
Kallmann syndrome is a condition characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell. This disorder is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which is a condition resulting from a lack of production of certain hormones that direct sexual development.

          Kallmann's Syndrome
• It is a form of Hypogonadotrophic Hypogonadism (HH).
• Failure of communication between the hypothalamus and the anterior pituitary gland.
• Hypothalamic neurons (GNRH neurons) fail to migrate into the hypothalamus during embryonic development.

Clinical Features:
• Puberty failure
• Lack of testicle development in men
• Primary amenorrhea or failure to start menstruation in women
• Poorly defined secondary sexual characteristics
• Infertility
• Cleft palate or other craniofacial defects.
• Anosmia or hyposmia

Investigations
• Low serum testosterone
• Low serum estrogens
• Low levels of LH and FSH
• Karyotype
• X-ray
• MRI

Mode of inheritance:
• Genetic mutations in the KAL-I gene (X-linked) or as an
   autosomal dominant or recessive fashion.

Treatment:
Menstruation can be induced with combined estrogen and progestin
therapy. Induction of ovulation is successful with exogenous gonadotropins.


i

questions.text: What do lactating women need more than pregnant women?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A
  • Vitamin A (retinol) and provitamin A carotenoids are normal components of human milk.
  • The recommend dietary intake in lactating women is 1300 mcg retinol daily, compared to 770 mcg daily during pregnancy.
  • Breast milk is the primary source of Vitamin A for the infant, so the demand for it increases during lactation to support the baby's needs.

questions.text: Identify this tool used in PAP smears:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Ayre's spatula.
 
  • Ayre's spatula is a medical instrument used primarily for collecting cervical cell samples during a Pap smear (Papanicolaou test). It is a flat, wooden or plastic spatula with a curved, elongated shape, designed to gently scrape cells from the ectocervix (the outer part of the cervix) to screen for cervical cancer, precancerous conditions, and other abnormalities.
 
  • In practice, it is often used in combination with a cytobrush to collect samples from the endocervix (the canal within the cervix).

questions.text: Which fixative is used in a PAP smear?
questions.solution:
The fixative used is 95% ethyl alcohol+ 5% ether
 

The fixative commonly used in a Pap smear is 95% ethanol or a similar alcohol-based solution. The purpose of the fixative is to preserve the cells collected from the cervix, preventing them from drying out or undergoing further changes before staining.

Types of fixative used:

  1. 95% Ethanol:
    • Most commonly used.
    • Ensures rapid fixation and good preservation of cellular details.
  2. Alcohol-based Fixatives:
    • May contain ethanol, methanol, or isopropanol.
    • Commercially available in spray forms, often used immediately after sample collection to prevent air-drying of cells.
  3. Carbowax (Alcohol-based Fixative with Polyethylene Glycol):
    • Used in spray fixatives to create a coating over the cells.
    • Prevents air-drying and helps preserve the sample until it can be stained.
Importance of proper fixation: 
 
  • Prevents Air-Drying: Cells that air-dry can become distorted, which makes microscopic evaluation difficult.
  • Preserves Morphology: Fixatives maintain the structure of both the nucleus and cytoplasm, which is essential for accurate diagnosis.
Fixative used in liquid based cytology is methanol. 


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: A USG abdomen of a 20-week-pregnant female is shown below. What is the most likely anomaly?
questions.solution:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄãCorrect option is 1: Anencephaly.
 
  • The sagittal plane of the provided USG scan reveals anencephaly.
  • The loss of cortical tissue and the absence of the cranial vault describe anencephaly, the most severe type of cranial neural tube defect (NTD). However, the brainstem and cerebellum may occasionally be present.
Anencephaly:
  • Most severe form of cranial neural tube defect (NTD)
  • Occurs due to failure of closure of rostral neuropore leading to failed crania vault development and unprotected exposed brain tissue (exencephaly).
  • Subsequent destruction/autolysis leaves a flattened, amorphous vascular-neural mass characteristic of anencephaly. 
Antenatal ultrasound:
 
  • Sonographically detectable as early as 11 weeks. 
  • Sonographic features of anencephaly include:
  • Absence of parenchymal tissue above the orbits along with calvarium 
  • Small amount of neural tissue may be present which is termed as exencephaly
  • Less than expected value for crown-rump length (CRL)
  • "Frog eye" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance- Seen in coronal plane due to absent cranial bone along with brain and bulging orbits
  • Polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Vulval Hematoma
The picture is self explanatory and depicts a Vulval Hematoma.
 
  • A tense, tender swelling of varying size rapidly develops, encroaches on the vaginal lumen, and causes overlying skin or epithelium to become ecchymotic. However, symptoms of pelvic pressure, pain, or inability to void should prompt evaluation.
  • Vulvovaginal hematomas are managed according to their size, location, duration since delivery, and expansion. If bleeding ceases, then small- to moderate-sized hematomas may be treated expectantly until absorbed. Cool packs and analgesics are supportive care, and an inability to void merits catheter drainage. But, if pain is severe or if the hematoma continues to enlarge, surgical exploration is preferable.
  • For repair, an incision is made at the point of maximal distention, blood and clots are evacuated, and bleeding points ligated.

questions.text: What is the specific problem with monochorionic twins?
questions.solution:
1. TWIN TWIN TRANSFUSION SYNDROME- 

Vein-to-vein, artery-to-artery, or artery-to-vein anastomosis are possible between twins (VV). 

The receiver twin receives blood transfusions from the donor twin, which could eventually cause anemia and limit the donor's ability to grow. On the other hand, the recipient develops polycythemia and could experience circulatory overload that looks like hydrops. Recipient twin has a better prognosis compared to donor twin.  

It is always present in monochorionic placentas. 

Contrary to monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy, M/C occurs in monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which are the drugs used in the treatment of severe COVID-19 infection in children?

questions.text: Which of the following describes the proper set of physiological jaundice changes?
questions.solution:
The term "physiologic" refers to jaundice brought on by these changes, and it is thought to be the result of increased bilirubin synthesis from the destruction of foetal red blood cells in combination with a temporary restriction in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature newborn liver. 

Characterised by Increased indirect bilirubin, normal urine bilirubin and increased urine urobilinogen. 

Jaundice usually becomes apparent on the second or third day after birth, peaking between the second and fourth days at 5–6 mg/dL, and then declining to 2 mg/dL between the fifth and seventh days. Under normal circumstances, the level of indirect bilirubin in umbilical cord serum is 1-3 mg/dL and rises at a rate of 5 mg/dL/24 hr

questions.text:
A 2-day-old child presents with a ballotable abdominal mass not crossing midline and h/o hematuria. Which among the following investigations should be carried out?
i. CT Abdomen
ii. CT Chest
iii. FNAC
iv. VMA assessment
questions.solution:
• Wilms tumor is the most likely diagnosis based on the child's examination and history(Ballotable mass + hematuria). Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor. 
  • Abdominal imaging studies such as CT of the abdomen are used to pinpoint the mass' intrarenal origin and distinguish it from abdominal masses such as neuroblastomas and adrenal masses. 
  • CT Chest is done to evaluate for metastatic lesions. (Lungs are the most common site of metastasis)
  • While typically imaging suffices for making a diagnosis - FNAC can be considered if the diagnosis is unclear. However, a biopsy is avoided as it upstages the disease. 
  • Urinary VMA is used for diagnosis of suspected Neuroblastoma - will not be sent in the case of suspected Wilms tumor as the mass is ballotable/not crossing the midline and CT Abdomen will further confirm the renal origin of the mass. (VMA is not sent in case of every abdominal mass - only if Neuroblastoma is suspected on imaging - it is sent)


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 609,610

choices.text: About 20-30% of CMV infections are symptomatic at birth
A triad of hearing loss, PDA and cataract is seen
Hearing loss can appear later in life in asymptomatic babies
Babies born to mothers who have IgG CMV are always 100% immune to the transplacental spread

questions.text: Which of the following statement about congenital CMV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct asnwer is option(3).
 
  • 90% of neonates with congenital CMV infections are asymptomatic at birth and will not show any clinical symptoms. However, 10% of infected newborns present with symptoms. Hence, option 1 is incorrect.(10% of babies are symptomatic, not 20-30%)
  • Infants with symptomatic congenital CMV infections typically have a triad of Jaundice, Petechiae, and hepatosplenomegaly.  A triad of hearing loss, PDA, and cataracts is seen in congenital Rubella syndrome, not CMV.
  • The most frequent long-term complication of neonatal CMV infection is hearing loss (SNHL) - It is the most common cause of non-syndromic SNHL. Around 50% of newborns with congenital CMV infection go on to experience hearing loss in later infancy and early childhood. Hence, option 3 is correct.
  • CMV can also be transmitted from mother to fetus if the mother had a CMV infection in the past and was immune at the time of conception. This transmission can occur due to reinfection during pregnancy. Hence, option 4 is incorrect. 

Answer has been confirmed with Professors of both Microbiology and Pediatrics at AIIMS, Delhi. It's given wrong in many Qbanks.
 

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1719-1720

questions.text:
Retigabine is being used to treat a patient with a seizure disorder (focal seizures), although the patient's seizures are not under control at this time.
Which of the following sentences represents the right next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 2)  Increase the dose of retigabine
 
  1. Individuals with lower serum protein levels (for example, lower serum albumin due to poor liver or renal function) may have a higher ratio of free to bound drug, but the concentration of free drug may still be sufficient to control seizures in these patients. 
  2. Some patients may have "subtherapeutic" drug levels, but the dose shouldn't be changed solely to get to a "therapeutic" level; it should only be changed if seizures aren't under control. 
  3. It becomes required to switch to another antiepileptic medication if seizures persist after steady increases to the maximum tolerated dose and confirmed compliance.
  4. This is typically accomplished by keeping the patient on the first medication while introducing a second one. 
  5. To reduce seizure frequency without producing toxicity, the dose of the second medication needs to be changed. 
  6. When this is accomplished, the initial medication can be progressively discontinued (usually over weeks unless there is significant toxicity).
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who first had weakness in his right lower limb then, within a year, in his left lower limb. He has been experiencing distal upper limb weakness, increased tone, and rapid reflexes in the last two months. Neither sensory loss nor bladder dysfunction have a history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ALS

 
* CLINICAL MANIFESTATIONS:
 
  • Asymmetric weakness that slowly develops and usually manifests itself distally in one of the limbs. 
  • Sudden onset of cramping during voluntary movements, usually in the early morning (e.g., while stretching in bed). 
  • Muscle atrophy and progressive muscular withering.
  • fasciculations, or the spontaneous twitching of motor units, early in the illness. 
  • Extensor weakness predominates over flexor weakness in the hands. 
  • Early denervation affects bulbar muscles as opposed to limb muscles, and the condition initially manifests as difficulty chewing, swallowing, and moving the face and tongue. 
  • Muscle-stretch reflexes are overactive (tendon jerks), and there is frequently spastic resistance to passive motions of the affected limbs. 
  • Muscle stiffness frequently outweighs weakness. 
  • Cognitive, digestive and bladder, and sensory functioning are unaffected.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3410.

questions.text: Neuromyelitis spectrum disorder can be diagnosed in all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:

  • The more inclusive term NMO spectrum disorder (NMOSD) was proposed to include individuals with partial forms, and also those with involvement of additional regions in the central nervous system.

questions.text:
A patient has been admitted to the emergency room with a possible acid-base disorder. Which of the following is most likely to help with the diagnosis?
(i) pH of arterial blood
(ii) pH of venous blood
(iii) pO2 of venous blood
(iv) pCO2 of venous blood
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. (i), (ii). Arterial and Venous pH can be used to identify acid-base disorders.

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is considered the gold standard for evaluating oxygen and acid-base status. Venous blood gas (VBG) analysis is increasingly being adopted as an alternative to ABG, as the difference in pH between VBG and ABG is clinically insignificant (with arterial pH generally 0.03 higher than venous pH), rendering venous pH values acceptable. 

Other options:  
 
  • Option 3: The pO2 values exhibit a notable difference, as arterial pO2 (normal 95 mmHg) is usually 55 mmHg higher than venous pO2 (normal 40 mmHg), which makes venous pO2 values unacceptable.  
  • Option 4: Venous pCO2 (normal range 41 to 51 mmHg) values show a significant discrepancy from arterial pCO2 (normal range 35 to 45 mmHg), varying by 5 to 15 mmHg, thus rendering venous pCO2 values unacceptable.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 360.

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology.14th edition, Page no 1085.

choices.text: Start TB treatment first 2 weeks later ART
Start ART first and later merge with ATT

questions.text: A patient tested positive for both tuberculosis and HIV. Which of the following is the next best management step?
questions.solution:
Due to immunological suppression, HIV infection increases the likelihood that a new M. tuberculosis infection will develop into TB illness quickly. Start TB treatment first, followed by ART as soon as possible after starting TB treatment within the first 8 weeks of treatment.
 
  • HIV-positive TB patients with profound immunosuppression (e.g., CD4+ < 50/μl) should receive ART within the first two weeks of initiating TB treatment.
  • Initiation of ART and/or anti-TB therapy may be associated with clinical deterioration due to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) reactions which is caused the viral proteins. These are most common in patients initiating both treatments at the same time, may occur as early as 1 week after initiation of ART therapy, and are seen more frequently in patients with advanced HIV disease.
 
  • For these reasons it is recommended that initiation of ART be delayed in antiretroviral-naïve patients with CD4 counts >50 cells/μL until 2–4 weeks following the initiation of treatment for TB.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1546, 1567.

questions.text: Which test is considered to be the gold standard for myocarditis diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Endomyocardial biopsy
 
  • The gold standard for determining the cause of myocarditis and providing a conclusive diagnosis is an endomyocardial biopsy.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy is indicated when a new presentation of heart failure is accompanied by conduction blocks or ventricular tachyarrhythmias, which suggest possible etiologies of noninfectious inflammatory causes that warrant aggressive immunosuppression, such as sarcoidosis or giant cell myocarditis.
  • The indications, yield, and benefit of endomyocardial biopsy for evaluation of myocarditis or new-onset cardiomyopathy are not well established.
  • MRI is the best option because non-invasive inquiry is recommended in the current scenario.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1930, 1932, 1959.
