questions.text:
Ergotamine is taken by an ART-treated HIV patient for migraine. After a few hours, her limbs feel cold, and her lower limbs' distal pulses are absent.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ergotism is the result of chronic ergot poisoning, which is traditionally brought on by consuming the alkaloids made by the fungus Claviceps purpurea.
  • The fungus's ergotamine-ergocristine alkaloids cause vasoconstriction, which leads to dry gangrene.
  • It affects the distal structures that have less blood flow, like the fingers and toes.
  • Desquamation or peeling, weak peripheral pulses, loss of peripheral feeling, edema, and eventually the death and loss of affected tissues are some of the symptoms.
  • Vasodilators are used to treat vasoconstriction.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3584, 3590.

questions.text: What is measured by the assessment of the brachial artery's change in diameter after a 5-minute arterial occlusion?
questions.solution:
Flow-mediated dilation is a non-invasive technique used to evaluate endothelial function by measuring the dilation of the brachial artery in response to increased blood flow (reactive hyperemia) after releasing a cuff that has occluded blood flow for 5 minutes.
The degree of dilation is an indicator of endothelial function and vascular health.


Reference: Maltz, Jonathan S et al. “Measurement of brachial artery endothelial function using a standard blood pressure cuff.” Physiological measurement vol. 36,11 (2015): 2247-68. doi:10.1088/0967-3334/36/11/2247

choices.text: NOAC ( New oral Anticoagulants) are used in atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis
Patients with ischemic stroke due to Atrial Fibrilation can be started on anticoagulation

questions.text: <strong>Consider the following statements in AF patients:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 2, 3 are correct

Novel Oral Anticoagulants (NOACs), also referred to as direct oral anticoagulants, comprise a new category of anticoagulants that includes the oral thrombin inhibitor dabigatran and oral factor Xa inhibitors such as rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. These medications are user-friendly, provide reliable anticoagulation, and do not necessitate dosage adjustments based on blood testing. Compared to warfarin, they have a lower risk of intracranial hemorrhage and serve as alternatives for patients with atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Statement 1: NOACs are not recommended for treating moderate to severe mitral stenosis (MS) due to limited clinical evidence regarding their efficacy and safety in this condition. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for patients with mitral stenosis and mechanical prosthetic valves.
  • Statement 2: NOACs are contraindicated in individuals with prosthetic mechanical heart valves because of insufficient evidence. Warfarin is given in such cases. 
  • Statement 3: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation, anticoagulation with either warfarin or NOACs is recommended. In cases of small or moderate-sized infarcts without intracranial bleeding, warfarin can be initiated shortly (after 24 hours) following admission, as the risk of transitioning to hemorrhagic stroke is minimal. NOACs can be started after 48 hours due to their quicker anticoagulant effects.
  • Statement 4: Beta blockers and CCBs are first line drugs used to achieve rate control in AF.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 935, 1905-1907.

questions.text:
While running, one athlete fell and passed away instantly. The heart's autopsy region is shown.
Which of the following statements about the condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
 
  • This is a case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The most common cause of death is ventricular arrythmia.
  • Major clinical problems in HCM are atrial fibrillation, mural thrombus formation leading to embolization and possible stroke, intractable cardiac failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and, not infrequently, sudden death, especially with certain mutations.
  • Indeed, HCM is one of the most common causes of sudden, otherwise unexplained death in young athletes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from hand and arm pain. She feels discomfort from the cascading water on her fingers even while cleaning dishes. On MRI, a lacunar infarct is discovered. Which of the aforementioned structures is most likely to experience an infarction?
questions.solution:
According to the history provided and the MRI results, thalamic pain syndrome is most likely to be responsible (a.k.a Dejerine–Roussy syndrome). is a condition brought on by thalamic damage from a stroke. Thalamic lesions can result from ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.    

Clinical traits:Is frequently preceded by numbness on the side being affected. Hypersensitivity can also cause burning and tingling, typically in the form of allodynia or dysaesthesia.
 
Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition page no 173

questions.text:
Skin lesion are present on the patient. A biopsy was performed, and the lesion's histopathology is displayed.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. From the provided histology image we can observe there is a suprabasilar blister, a portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof which is normally seen in Pemphigus vulgaris
  2. The various hpe features of Pemphigus Vulgaris include 
  • Acantholysis: Loss of cell-to-cell adhesion between keratinocytes.
  • Suprabasal blister: Separation just above the basal layer of the epidermis.
  • Tombstone appearance: Basal keratinocytes remain attached to the basement membrane, resembling tombstones. 
  • Direct immunofluorescence (DIF): IgG and C3 deposits in a “fishnet” or “chicken wire” pattern between keratinocytes.
Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text:
A young child has an itchy, hyperpigmented plaque with exudation on the back of the knee and elbow flexural, as illustrated.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atopic dermatitis
 
  • Psoriasis primarily affects the extensor side, whereas hyperpigmented plaque with exudation covering flexural aspects of the elbow and knee in a youngster indicates Atopic dermatitis. 
  • A chronic, excruciatingly itchy skin disorder with blisters called dermatitis herpetiformis is linked to gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Erythematous papules and vesicles collected together at extensor locations are characteristic lesions. 
  • Pemphigus - Initial lesions are easily ruptured superficial vesicles and bullae that leave shallow erosions covered with crust and dried serum.




Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 364, 365.

questions.text: A patient arrives with the lesion in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Borderline leprosy:

  • The number of skin lesions is in between those of the two polar types. 
  • They could appear as macules, plaques, annular lesions, or odd-looking bands. - characterised by plaques that appear "punched-out." 
  • Lesions are sparser, drier, more insensitive, and contain fewer bacilli in smears and biopsies towards the tuberculoid end of the spectrum than they do towards the lepromatous pole.
Classification Symptoms Disease response
Tuberculoid leprosy A few flat lesions, some large and numb; some nerve involvement Can heal on its own, persist, or may progress to a more severe form
Borderline tuberculoid leprosy Lesions similar to tuberculoid but more numerous; more nerve involvement May persist, revert to tuberculoid, or advance to another form
Mid-borderline leprosy Reddish plaques; moderate numbness; swollen lymph nodes; more nerve involvement May persist, revert to tuberculoid, or advance to another form
Borderline lepromatous leprosy Many lesions, including flat lesions, raised bumps, plaques, and nodules; more numbness May persist, regress, or progress
Lepromatous leprosy Many lesions with bacteria; hair loss; more severe nerve involvement with peripheral nerve thickening; limb weakness; disfigurement Doesn't regress


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10, 28.7, 28.5

questions.text:
A 13-year-old kid presents to the OPD with segmented patches of patchy depigmented skin on the chest and belly.
A year ago, depigmentation began, and during the past few months, there has been no change. Mother recalls using topical steroids in the past, but they weren't very helpful. Which medical diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Clinically speaking, vitiligo is marked by well-defined milky-white macules that may also involve white hairs or poliosis. Vitiligo is an acquired skin disease with progressive melanocyte loss. 
  • The vitiligo segmental variant: One continuous segment is often affected, while two or more segments with ipsilateral or contralateral distribution have been observed. It is distinguished by a unilateral and segmental, or block-shaped, distribution of the lesions. 
  • Little, discrete lesions make focal vitiligo. 
  • Piebaldism: A triangular-shaped white patch on the forehead, sporadic hypopigmented macules, and a congenitally white forelock are involved. 
  • Common areas for involvement include the forehead, chest, abdomen, and extremities. 
  • A well-defined hypopigmented patch called Nerve Depigmentosus is present from birth; it may occasionally become more noticeable in the first year of life as the background skin.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 88.37

questions.text:
A patient with painful lesions that were grouped together came to the STD clinic.
Which of the subsequent tests ought to be carried out to make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tzanck smear for multinucleate giant cells

 
  • Genital herpes is more commonly caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) 2. The patients present with painful vesicular-ulcerative lesions. In men, it occurs mainly on the penis or urethra. In women, the cervix, vagina, vulva, and perineum can be involved. 
  • Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes.
  • The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. 
  • The Tzanck smear technique is a rapid and inexpensive diagnostic method. Scrapings (preferably from the base of vesicles) are obtained from the lesions and stained with a  1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. 
  • Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, known as Tzanck cells, are seen. Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles in Giemsa-stained smears.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 31.22, 31.23

questions.text: Which disease is covered in the ICD 11 category of body-focused repetitive behaviour?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Trichotillomania.
 
  • Body-focused repetitive behavior (BFRB) is an umbrella name for impulse control behaviors involving damage to one's physical appearance or causing physical injury.
  • These disorders include 
  1. Trichotillomania(hair pulling)
  2. Skin-Picking (Dermatotillomania)
  3. Onychophagia (nail biting).

Reference: Grant, Jon E, and Dan J Stein. “Body-focused repetitive behavior disorders in ICD-11.” Revista brasileira de psiquiatria (Sao Paulo, Brazil : 1999) vol. 36 Suppl 1 (2014): 59-64. doi:10.1590/1516-4446-2013-1228 
Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 286.

questions.text: The following are excluded from the diagnosis of neuromyelitis spectrum disorders:
questions.solution:
Focal epilepsy is NOT included in diagnostic criteria for NMOSD.

NEUROMYELITIS OPTICA SPECTRUM DISORDERS (NMOSD):
Diagnosis according to AQP4-IgG-seropositive status
• \(\geq\)1 core clinical characteristic
• Positive test for AQP4-IgG
• Exclusion of alternative diagnoses
 
Six core NMOSD clinical characteristics
• Optic neuritis • Acute myelitis
• Area postrema syndrome • Acute brainstem syndrome
• Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome
• Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD-typical brain lesions
 
Diagnosis according to AQP4-IgG-seronegative status
• \(\geq\)2 different core clinical characteristics as a result of \(\geq\)1 clinical
   attack and meeting all following requirements:
    • \(\geq\)1 core clinical characteristic must be ON, acute myelitis with
       LETM or area postrema syndrome
    • Dissemination in space (\(\geq\)2 different core clinical characteristics)
    • Fulfilment of additional MRI requirements
• Negative test for AQP4-IgG
• Exclusion of alternative diagnoses

Additional MRI requirements for NMOSD without AQP4-IgG and NMOSD with unknown AQP4-IgG status
 
  1. Acute optic neuritis: requires brain MRI showing (a) normal findings or only nonspecific white matter lesions, OR (b) optic nerve MRI with T2-hyperintense lesion or T1-weighted gadolinium-enhancing lesions extending over \(\geq\)1/2 optic nerve length or involving optic chiasm
  2. Acute myelitis: requires associated intramedullary MRI lesion extending over \(\geq\)3 contiguous segments (LETM) OR \(\geq\)3 contiguous segments of focal spinal cord atrophy in patients with history compatible with acute myelitis
  3. Area postrema syndrome: requires associated dorsal medulla/area postrema lesions
  4. Acute brainstem syndrome: requires associated periependymal brainstem lesions


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3477.

questions.text: Off-label uses of Risperidone are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bipolar disorder

Risperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic approved by FDA to treat
  • Schizophrenia
  • Bipolar disorder
  • Autism-associated irritability 
  • Resistant depression- in combination with antidepressants
Hence, Bipolar disorder is not an off-label use - rather an approved use of Risperidone.
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 468.

choices.text: Suicide- self-harm without an intention of causing death.
Overworking- excess work but according to ones capacity.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old physician works in the emergency room and frequently works at night.
Which of the following statements about his mental health is correct?
questions.solution:
The syndrome of burnout is thought to be brought on by ongoing workplace stress that has not been effectively controlled. It has three characteristics:
  1. emotions of weariness or depletion of energy; 
  2. increasing mental detachment from one's employment; sentiments of pessimism or cynicism regarding one's career; 
  3. Decreased professional efficacy. 
  • Depression is a mental health condition that significantly impairs daily life and is characterized by a persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities.    
  • Suicide is self-directed, possibly harmful conduct that is non fatal and has the primary goal of causing death. 
  • Working more than your typical working hours and beyond your capacity is referred to as overworking.



Reference: Ventriglio, Antonio et al. “Suicide among doctors: A narrative review.” Indian journal of psychiatry vol. 62,2 (2020): 114-120. doi:10.4103/psychiatry.IndianJPsychiatry_767_19
Kishor, M et al. “Suicide among Indian doctors.” Indian journal of psychiatry vol. 63,3 (2021): 279-284. doi:10.4103/psychiatry.IndianJPsychiatry_137_20
